intro: Rhododendron catawbiense, commonly known as the Catawba rhododendron, is a species native to the Appalachian Mountains in the eastern United States. It is a deciduous shrub that typically grows to a height of 3 to 6 meters, featuring dense, leathery leaves that are dark green on top and lighter underneath. The plant produces showy clusters of pink to reddish-purple flowers in the spring, which are borne on long, pendulous inflorescences. Its botanical characteristics include opposite, ovate leaves and a preference for acidic, well-drained soils. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and landscapes.
